div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE KHEDIVE AND THE "TIMES."
div.p: The following are the criticisms of the " Times " on the recent declarations of the Khedive :—.

— There was a time, only a few years ago, when such an interview as that which the Khedive has granted to a French journalist, and our Paris Correspondent reports to-day, would have given occasion for grave uneasiness. That we can now afford to regard it as nothing more than an unpleasant reminder of the Khedive's usual attitude towards this country is a sign of the increased strength of our position in Egypt, and still more of our cordial relations with the other Power chiefly interested in Northern Africa. The whole character of the Khedive's remarks invites this reflection, though it shows only too plainly that the change is none of his seeking. But even if the tone of the interview did not suggest this contrast between the present and the past, His Highness has added a curious remark at the end which would make it impossible for us to forget the fact. He gave his interlocutor, the special correspondent of the "Temps," a greeting to the French people with these enigmatic words:—" We do not forget what they have been for us, and we are very fond of them " all the same. " It is the French journalist who italicized the words which our Paris Correspondent has reported. If they mean anything, there is only one meaning they can bear. The Khedive dates the strain which France has put upon his friendship from her conclusion of the entente with us. Provisions about Egypt, like provisions about Morocco, formed an integral part of the agreement, and it is as a result of them, and of their loyal observance by France, that we have been able to carry on our salutary work in Egypt with no fear of vexatious obstruction. To any one who protests his devotion to his country's welfare so strongly as the Khedive this ought to be a matter for genuine satisfaction. But it is evidently to the period before the entente that His Highness's pleasant recollections are confined—a period when French interests were inconstant antagonism to our own, and when the progress and security of Egypt were exposed to continual risk on account of this friction. We do not suppose for a moment that the French people will take the Khedive's view of recent history. If they continue in friendly intercourse with Egypt, we shall be as gratified as His Highness, but we do not think they will show a disposition to return to the attitude that preceded the entente. The mutual benefits of the entente, moral and material, are too well realized, the solidarity of our interests in Northern Africa is too plain, for either nation to be willing to disturb it at the prompting of an interested third party.

The substance of the Khedive's remarks is, we are sorry to say, in only too faithful agreement with his final innuendo. No one ignorant of the modern history of Egypt, and going to this conversation for enlightenment, would guess even remotely what its course had been. He would imagine the Egyptians to be a people who had worked out their own salvation. He would suppose this to have been done under the beneficent initiative of Abbas II.—a much-suffering ruler who, however, even in the darkest moments never relaxed his ungrudging efforts for his people's good. That the country had been brought out of distracted anarchy by the tutelage of another Power ; that this Power had preserved both the dynasty and the safety of its heritage — all this would never dawn on one who took his history from the Khedive. Yet the father of Abbas II. owed his retention of the throne to us. His Highness himself owes his personal security and the integrity of his dominions to the support of British power. The material develo­ment of his country, on which he dwells with complacency, is due similarly to Great Britain ; for, as a French writer pointed out in the Depeche Coloniale the other day, it was she who inspired capital with confidence and attracted it to Egypt, by consolidating the political situation, establishing order in the administration and finances, and undertaking the great public works in aid of commerce and agriculture. At one or two points of the interview, it is true, the Khedive tries to reassure opinion. He declares emphatically that it is wrong to assume that the "national" claims are anti-foreign and fanatic. We would gladly accept that assurance, but we cannot forget that it is precisely the same as those lavished by the notorious agitator Mustapha Pasha Kamel, whose national patriotism is of an unmistakably anti-British brand. Though His Highness deprecates the idea that he could possibly become a despot, it would not be too much to say that, in the necessarily restricted sphere where he now wields personal authority, it bears every mark of arbitrariness. Nor can a single-minded devotion to progress be seriously claimed by a ruler who has stood aside, often ostentatiously, from our efforts to benefit Egypt, and who allows favouritism and corruption to be rife in the public departments which still come within his influence.
The "Times" concludes with the following comments on the letter of Sir Christopher Furness, of which a telegraphic summary has appeared in a former issue.

A truer picture of the real Egypt, and of the men who have made it, is to be gathered from the instructive letter by Sir Christopher Furness M. P, He has returned from a stay in Egypt, " where the extraordinary results of British administrative genius, ' as he says, " compel admiration." But having enough experience of men and cities to know that a short tour in another land does not qualify the visitor to say the last word about it, he tells us that he would not have raised his protest against the policy pursued by a fellow Liberal, Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P., if he did not know that Mr. Robertson's acquaintance with Egypt were no greater than his own. But Mr. Robertson, and other Englishmen who like traducing the work of their country abroad, never allow the scantiness of their knowledge to stop them. Where their aspersions come into touch with facts they can generally be refuted without much trouble, as Sir Christopher Furness refutes them in a single particular by his effective account of the reform of justice under Lord Cromer's administration. Nor do the traducers carry enough weight at home for sensible people to pay much attention to them. But it is otherwise among the native populations with whom they are constantly making mischief, and to the credulous, excitable Egyptian public it may seem a matter of real significance that letters by Mr. Robertson, a British member of Parliament and one of the Government's supporters, should appear in the Cairo "Standard," Mustapha Kamel's Nationalist organ. As regards British policy it is of no significance, unless it be significant that, after the severe handling he received from Sir Edward Grey last summer, Mr. Robertson should have thought it safer to transfer his reflections from the House of Commons to a Cairene journal. But native readers do not appreciate this, and all the heavier, therefore, is the responsibility of those Europeans who seek to play on their ignorance and fanaticism. Influences of this kind, whether consciously or unconsciously exerted, are not confined to Egypt. The French, who are now deploring the brutal assasination of a fellow-countryman in Morocco, are inclined to read in this regrettable event another sign of the mischievous effect which political intrigues in Europe have had on the receptive Moorish mind.

div.head: Luxor Winter Palace
div.p: In consequence of the Luxor Winter Palace being still half full, the management have decided not to close it until the 15th inst.

div.head: H.M.S. Minerva.
div.p: H.M.S Minerva is due at Port Said from Malta to-day and it is expected that she will make a stay of some six months in Egyptian waters.

div.head: Death Sentence.
div.p: The execution of Abd el Mewla Mohamed, found guilty of wilful murder, will take place at Alexandria prison at ten o'clock to-morrow morning.

div.head: Rabies In Alexandria,
div.p: The Alexandria Municipality have given notice that in consequence of cases of rabies having recently occurred, mainly at Ramleh, all dogs must not only carry their registration number but must also either be muzzled or led on a leash.

div.head: Salaries of Tribunal Officials.
div.p: The commission appointed by the Ministry of Justice to study the question of raising the salaries of the staff of the Native Tribunals and Mehkemehs Sharieh, has concluded its work, and will submit its report shortly to the Ministry of Finance.

div.head: The Mosque Students.
div.p: The grand sheikh of the Ulemas at Alexandria is undertaking the provision of respectable lodgings for the poorer students of the mosques of Alexandria, and each of these will be supplied with a free bed. Two Alexandrian notables have subscribed forty beds.

div.head: Mr. Moore Acquitted.
div.p: The official inquiry into the Ministry of Public Works scandal has now been closed. Mr. Moore was discharged from the suspicion of corruption imputed to him, but Ahmed Effendi El-Sarfani and another official of that ministry were found guilty. They were therefore arrested and will be brought shortly before the court for trial.

div.head: Wakfs Supreme Council.
div.p: The Supreme Council of Wakfs which met yesterday in Cairo, under the presidency of Adli Pasha Yaghen, has decided to grant the Mohamed Aly and the Damanhour Industrial Schools L.E. 1,000 and LE. 500, respectively, as annual graints-in-aid. The Council has also decided to appoint a native physician to accompany pilgrims to Mecca in future.

div.head: Train de Luxe Collision.
div.p: We are officially informed that early yesterday morning the train de luxe running from Luxor to Cairo was wrongly admitted into a siding at Manfeloot station and collided with a goods train standing in the siding. None of the passengers were hurt, but the brakesman of the train de luxe sustained slight injury. The traffic was considerably delayed by the accident.

div.head: Egypt's Trade
div.p: Prof Arminjon, who recently issued a book on the Mohammedan Universities of Cairo, has now published (through the house of Larose of Paris, in the transactions of a publication society which bears the name of M Sirey Le commerce extérieur de l'Egypte. It is to be commended to all who are interested in trade statistics. The newest point in the thin volume is the proof given that the construction of the Suez Canal was fatal to a large Egyptian transport, entrepôt, and re-exportation business.

div.head: The Russian Concert
div.p: The concert given yesterday afternoon at the New Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria, by the celebrated Russian artists, Miss Vera and Miss Nadesda Chernetzka, was a great success, and all those who were fortunate enough to be present were delighted with the magnificent execution and technique of these Russian ladies. The programme included some of the choicest works of modern composers. Miss Nadesda Cberuetzka is a splendid contralto and her renderings from Glinka's "La Vie pour le Czar," Saint Saëns' 'Samson et Delila," the "Habauera" in "Carmen," and "Les Cloches" of Taskin were enthusiastically applauded. Miss Vera Chernetzka's, the pianist, execution of Back's Orgue Toccata et Fugue D. Moll (Tansig) and Tschakowski's paraphrase were especially noteworthy. These ladies will give a second concert at the New Khedivial Hotel,.on Thursday next at 9.30 p.m.

div.head:
LORD CROMER.
SITUATION IN EGYPT.
IMPORTANT INTERVIEW.
div.p: The account of an important interview with Lord Cromer appears in the "Temps." The interview was granted to M. René Puaux and took place recently at Cairo. His Lordship expressed the great satisfaction which he felt at the recent revival of French interest in Egypt. He always had the interests of the Anglo-French "entente cordiale" at heart and the agreement between the two countries was felt in Egypt as making for the policy of progress which he is pursuing.

Lord Cromer then went on to speak of his report on Egypt for 1906. He declared that he again treats of the subject of the Capitulations in this report but does not deal with them with a view to their suppression but with the object of adapting them to the modern conditions prevailing in Egypt by transferring their legal functions to Great Britain.

Lord Cromer made some important observations on one of the developments of the extraordinary financial and commercial prosperity of Egypt, and expressed some anxiety about the great increase in the numbers of the new companies, which had been floated of late on the local market. M René Puaux in commenting on their animadversions of his Lordship added that the slightly pessimistic tone in Lord Cromer's allusions to this subject were easily comprehensible as coming from a man of such proverbial integrity, as was acknowledged even by his adversaries, and were inspired by a dislike of the profits not produced by work.

div.head: THE DUKE OF CONNAUGHT.
div.p: At eleven o'clock yesterday morning H.R.H the Duke of Connaught paid a visit to H.H. the Khedive at Abdin Palace, and shortly after midday the Khedive returned the Duke's visit at the British Agency.
In the afternoon His Royal Highness, accompanied by Major-General Sir John Maxwell, and Mr. Myles Ponsonby, visited Count von Moers at the Semiramis Hotel.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: We understand that El-Miralai Asser Bey will be promoted to the rank of Lewa and appointed Adjutant General of the Egyptian Army. The appointment of such a capable and popular officer to this high post will, we are sure, be received with great satisfaction throughout all the Army.
We sincerely congratulate El-Lewa Asser Pasha upon his well deserved promotion.
The following transfers and appointments have been approved :—
El Miralai J. J. Asser Bey, Station Commandant, Khartoum to be Adjutant General.
El Kaimakam W. H. Drake Bey, Deputy Assistant Adjutant General, to be Assistant Adjutant General.
El Kaimakam C. H. Townsend Bey, Assistant Adjutant General, to Sudan Government.
El Kaimakam G. F. Clayton Bey, Sudan Government, to the Army, for duty on His Excellency the Sirdar's Staff.
El Bimbashi W. J. St J. Aarvey, 9th Sudanese, to be Deputy Assistant Adjutant General.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)

La liquidation n'étant pas terminée, des réalisations forcées font fléchir encore le cours de plusieurs de nos valeurs les plus en vue ainsi le Comptoir, la Building Lands et la Behera perdent respectivement 7 16, 3 8, et 5/8.
En baisse également de 1/16 la Ramleh et la Delta Light. La Nungovich recule d'une demi livre. Les Estates rétrogradent à 1 3/4.
L'Egyptian Construction et l'Investment à 31 32 la Salt & Soda à 9/9 et la United Land à 1 1/32.
De nombreuses transactions ont eu lieu en Agricole, National et Union foncière. En hausse de 1 16 l'Urbaine à 7 3/16 et les Ritz à 3 5/16. La tendance reste, indécise pour le moment.

Ce matin à 11 heures a eu lieu la vente aux enchères de 60 lots turcs ordonnée par le Tribunal Mixte de 1ère Instance d'Alexandrie au préjudice de la faillite S. Livanos. Le prix réalisé n'a té que de fr. 148,50. par titre.

Une maison de courtage de notre ville vient de cesser ses paiments. Son passif est peu important. L'Association des courtiers en valeurs a décidé que toutes les positions en suspens avec la dite agence seront compensées aux prix acheteurs de la clôture de Jeudi dernier soit le 28 Mars 1907. Pour les valeurs qui ne sont pas cotées à Alexandrie, les compensations ont lieu aux cours suivants : New Egyptien 23, L vico 1 5/16, Lunghis 1 3/16, Karam 13/16.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM.
THE KHEDIVE'S DECLARATIONS.
div.p: The declarations of the Khedive to M. Puaux are the subject of considerable comment in the local Press and it is assumed that the statements made by His Highneea on the subject of the national claims show that he has taken his position in the Egyptian Nationalist Party. The frankness, with which the Khedive specially alluded to the national claims should not be received with any uneasiness for it has long been known how much His Highness sympathised with that section of the natives, who are designated by the vague term "The Nationalist Party." On the contrary the fact that his Highness has emerged from his obscurity and publicly allowed his political ideals to be proclaimed to the world should do much to make the situation in Egypt clearer, especially in England.

La "Reforme" lays special stress on the Khedive's statements on the subject of "révendications nationales" and remarks "To-day the Khedive declares himself as the guarantor before the world of the sentiments of his subjects, and he defines the character of the national claims. It is in this phrase that all the importance of the interview granted to the distinguished representative of the "Temps" lies."

The "Progres" states that the remarks of the Khedive show that his Highness has taken his place in the ranks of the Nationalist Party. "None of the 'national claims' made by the "Lewa" and repeated by the National Assembly have been forgotten by the Khedive. The satisfaction of the intellectual and moral needs of the people, the co-operation of the nation with the Sovereign, all such statements form a fitting pendant in the interview with his denial, as to the existence of fanaticism, and his silence in regard to the Occupation. However, the declarations of the Khedive have one merit, namely in the fact that they have rendered all equivocation impossible. The Khedive declared that he never disdained advice. But this announcement is historically incorrect. However, if it shows a new disposition on the part of the Khedive the announcement is most opportune, for the Khedive never needed good advice more than he does now. The best advice to give him is to recall to his mind the history of the Princes, who are his immediate predecessors. He will see that the Khedive Ismail lost his throne because he fraternised with the National Party and that the Khedive Tewfik owed his throne to the Occupation, which crushed that party. The connection of the Khediviate with the National Party has always been fatal."

"Al Moayad" remarks: We have conned his Highness's declarations over and over again and cannot find a single word which his Highness should have left unsaid. As a native of high rank, as the ruler of Egypt, and as a Moslem Emir, who knows his religion and the circumstances of other religions in the East and West, the Khedive had the right to say every word of the declaration in question.

"Al Gerida" remarks :— "What in the Khedive's declarations can have offended the British? Is it because he did not give high praise to the Government ? The last sentences of his Highness's statements ("I have never opposed measures which I thought to be useful to Egypt I have never disdained advice.") can only mean that the prosperity of the country, to which he referred, was the fruit of the works of the Government, and necessarily through the advice of the occupants."

"Al Minbar" says:– "As we have already said the statements of the Khedive are simple and contain nothing extraordinary. Those who endeavour to associate his Highness with any political party are only the dukhala enemies of Egypt and the Egyptians, and also of the British. On reading the "Times" comments we could find nothing worthy of translation. Weakness and perplexity are evident in that paper's article".

div.head:
OBITUARY.
MR. E. C. HOGG.
div.p: We regret to announce the death of Mr. E. C. Hogg, which took place this morning at his Cairo residence at Ghezireh. He was recently attacked by pneumonia and his fragile constitution was incapable of resisting the malady. The death of Mr. Hogg will cause great regret at Cairo and Alexandria for he counted a large circle of friends in both cities. He wasabn old resident at Alexandria and had lived here for many years during his official career in the Coastguards Administration, which he joined from the Royal Navy. A few years ago be retired from the service and embarked as a stockbroker in Cairo, where he had considerable success and was trusted by a large number of clients who had an unfailing confidence in the sterling integrity of his character and the keenness of his judgment in financial matters.
He leaves a widow, the daughter of Mr. Peel of Alexandria, and a young family to deplore his loss.

div.head: THE IRISH DINNER.
div.p: The Irish dinner was held last night at the Grand Continental Hotel under the presidency of Mr. J. Langley. The dinner was largely attended, over fifty members of the Irish colony in Cairo being present. After the toast of the King had been honoured, Mr. Langley, in giving the toast of Ireland, expressed his deep regret at the sad event which had led to the postponement of the dinner. By the death of Mr. Verschoyle he had lost a dear friend and colleague.

The chairman then described the progress of the Irish dinner club, pointing out that it had trebled its number of members since the first dinner was given four years ago. He was glad to see so many members of the two famous Irish regiments, the Inniskilling Dragoons and the Inniskilling Fusiliers, who, he hoped would long remain in Cairo.
He then called upon every Irishman present to drink the toast of Ireland. No further speeches were made, and the rest of the evening passed quietly, an informal smoking concerned being organised.

Great credit is due to the secretary, Mr. L. B. Weldon, who spared no effort in organising the dinner, and we must not forget the band of the Inniskilling Fusiliers, who gave a fine selection of Irish airs.

Mills, S.W. Harrell, F.W. Godwin, C.J. Baker, L. Stephen, J.G Relin and G.J. Bayspool Porter. Qualification (except signatories while acting as provisional directors,) £10. Remuneration, £200 each per annum and a share in the profits as undermentioned ; 5 per cent. of any available profits is to be carried to reserve until such reserve reaches 10 per cent. of the paid-up capital, and afterwards 2½ per cent. of such profits (with a maximum of £10,000 in any year) is to be paid to each of the first managing directors as additional remuneration. The balance is to be applied first in payment of a cumulative preferential dividend of 5 per cent on the Ordinary shares. Of any surplus still remaining, 5 per cent. is to be paid to the directors as additional remuneration (with a maximum of £15,000 in any one year), 50 per cent. is to be applied as further dividend on the Ordinary shares or carried to reserve, or otherwise dealt with as the company in general meeting may determine, and 45 per cent is to be divided amongst the holders of the Founders' shares.

div.head:
END OF THE SEASON.
LAST SAVOY DANCE.
div.p: Though no dance was advertised for Saturday night at the Savoy, but rumours had gone abroad that the ballroom and orchestra would be available should they be wanted ; and as many people turned up for dinner and several big parties had been arranged, the evening terminated with quite one of the cheeriest dances of the season. Mrs. Berners was one of those who entertained quite a large party of friends, her guests including Lady Rogers, the Hon. C. Littleton, Capt. and Mrs. Rome, Miss Leverieh, Miss Hurley, Capt. and Mrs. Schreiber, Miss A. Reed, Miss Schreiber, Miss Yorke, Capt. Pardou, Mr. L Reid, Mr. F. Watson, Mr. Barton, Mr. K. Speir, and Mr. Barnard. Sir James also had a party, among whom were Mr. and Mrs. Appleton, Miss Fulpin, Miss Blyth, Col. Maberly, Col. Persse, Major Neil Haig, Capt. Mattheuws, Capt. Darrell, and Mr. Parker. Lord and Lady Carnarvon were entertaining Lord and Lady Lanesborough among their other guests. Mr. and Mrs. Smallman had a party of twelve, and Capt. and Mrs. Fitzgerald had guests with them, as had also Mr. and Mrs Peach. Mr. Horschitz was entertaining Mr. and Miss Bennett and Miss Ers ine Shaw ; and many of the officers of the various regiments were also dining in the restaurant. Quite a number of other residents arrived after dinner, and the dance, which was supposed to be quite an informal affair sans programmes, sans buffet, developed into one of the usual order, light refreshments being provided, and many suppers being ordered afterwards. Though there were plenty of dancers there was no crowd, and altogether this impromptu affair proved most successful.

We hear that there are to be no more dances this season at the Semiramis Hotel ; and it is probable that the one at Mena House this week will be the last of the series. Those on Monday night at Shepheard's may be continued for some weeks yet, but it is not likely that there will be any more at Ghezireh after this week.

div.head: STRIKE OF COAL HEAVERS
div.p: Our Port Said correspondent writes :—The coal discharging Arabs at this port have gone on strike, their demand being an increase in pay of 25 cts. per ton discharged. Some eight or nine colliers are in the harbour waiting to discharge, and the coal supply in the lighters is rapidly becoming exhausted. It is feared that influence is being brought to bear upon the coal-loading Arabs in order to make the strike general and that serious results may ensue.
Port Said, Tuesday.
The bunkering Arabs have joined the strike and the ships are compelled to coal with their own crews.

div.head: EASTER DAY AT ST. MARKS.
div.p: The Easter Festival celebrated on Sunday last was encouraging from every point of view. At the first service, 7 a.m, there were 19 communicants, at the 8 o'clook service 80, and at the midday service 72, a total of 171 compared with 141 in the previous year This must be greatly appreciated by Canon Ward, the Chaplain. The musical part of the services was excellently rendered and showed the care the choir had taken in rehearsing the music. The morning service opened with Hymn 134 sung to the well known "Ancient and Modern" tune, but whose author is unknown. The "Te Deum" by Vine Hall and the Choral Communion Service by Baptiste Calkin were carefully given and with good precision. We hope the choir will repeat these. The anthem in the morning was Myles Foster's "As it began to dawn towards the first day of the week, " which concludes with Bishop Wordsworth's Hymn " Allelulia ! Alleiulia ! Hearts and voices heavenward raise, " set to beautiful music by Foster. The solos were taken by Miss Maud Callender and Mr. Percy Smith, both being in excellent voice and singing well. The choir also acquitted themselves well. At the close of the morning service the National Anthem was sung. The Anthem "As it began to dawn" was repeated in the evening, when Vine Hall's "Magnificat" and "Nunc Dimittis" were beautifully given and reflected credit on the careful handling by the choir. The organist, Mr. Heaton gave valuable assistance throughout the day and at the close of each service gave Gaul's "Soldiers' March," from the Holy City." Special mention is due to the willing helpers, who so tastefully and appropriately decorated the Church. Miss Dodd was responsible for the pulpit; Miss Morrison and Miss Barwell for the font; Mrs Eyre and Miss Spurgeon for the lectern; Mrs. and Miss Roberts for the choir stalls : Miss Batcheller for the chapel; Mrs Algernon Ward for the altar gases. Among those who sent plants and flowers were Mmes. Borton, Crafton, Dickson, Foster, Hopkinson, Picton, Preston, W. T Smith, and Messrs. Batcheller, Coates, Morrison, and Messrs. Cornish and Ebell.
The offertory for the poor at the early services amounted to P T. 600 in addition to the Easter offering of P.T. 5,623 which was presented as usual to the assistant chaplain.

Lieutenant J H. J. Phillips, 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards, and Mrs. Phillips will embark for England on the Orotava on the 8th inst.

Sir Thomas Henry Elliot, K.C.B., whose death is reported by a Reuter's telegram, was born in London on September 7, 1854, and was the eldest son of the late Thomas Henry Elliot of Rue Ruhmkorff, Paris. He was educated privately and at the age of eighteen he entered the Inland Revenue Department by open competition. He was private Secretary to the Rt. Hon. C.T. Ritchie, when the latter was president of the Local Government Board, and for six years he was member of the Royal Commission on Local Taxation. Since 1892 he had been Secretary to the Board of Agriculture and Fisheries. He was created C B. in 1897 and and in 1902 was made K. C. B. He married a daughter of the late Jamas Rowe in 1880.

div.head: M. PUAUX IN EGYPT.
div.p: M. George Vayssié continues his career as a humorist of a high order. Saturday's "Journal du Cairo" contains a really brilliant parody of M. Puaux's letters to the "Temps" from which we take the following passage.

"The famous Paris journal "La Nuit" has just despatched to Egypt the equally famous reporter Dupont, the well known globe-trotter who discovered Naples and Vesuvius in 1906. We have been lucky enough to have communicated to us the eminent M. Dupont's first letter to "La Nuit" This is rare good fortune. We even give our readers the first view, for the article will be published in "La Nuit" before they appear in Paris.

"Notes by the way. At Sea. The sea is really a very curious thing. I don't really know why so much merriment has been expended on Marshal MacMahon. In the presence of the ocean he ejaculated "What a lot of water" and yet that is the cry that rises to one's lips in face of the boundless horizon........................ There is even too much of it, for excess is a defect. Shipwrecks in fact can only be attributed to a super-abundanoe of water ! The victims of the deep nearly always perish through submersion. Cases like the "Iena" disaster are decidedly rare. There is too much water below and around them. If there were less water below it the ship could ride out the storm resting on the bottom—if these were less all around the shipwrecked could easily gain dry land................. ...

In sight of the shore of Africa. I have just experienced a strong emotion. A sort of illuminated tower rises over there from the sea. I ask what it is. They reply "c'est Le Phare d'Alexandrie." Antiquities exercise a real fascination upon me. There is the celebrated monument which since Alexander's days has thrown its beams over the waters...
At Alexandria. Must confess my self quite astonished by my arrival at Alexandria.

Quite a European town. Good quays, docks and even carriages. Th-employes are decently dressed and appear to be able to write. In the streets few or none are completely naked. At the hotel my astonishment redoubles......On a table I find a copy of "La Nuit" Who would have believed it! They read "La Nuit" at Alexandria! And here are the "Figaro," "La Vie Parisienne." Some traveller must have left them here.….

The Great Interview. By the exercise of great skill I have at last obtained an interview with H H. the Khedive. I arranged the scheme of my questions with address, and thanks to my methods, the character and intentions of the Sovereign appear under a blinding light...I asked H. H. the Khedive, Abbas Hilmi the following questions.
" Is it true your Highness that you have prepared a coup d'etat against England for the night of March 31—April 1 next.

" This report is quite unfounded—I have prepared no such coup, for the excellent reason that I cannot. I should obviously be delighted to show Lord Cromer to the door, but as there is a chance of reciprocity being practised in these matters I prefer to abstain."
" Is it true that your Highness is a fanatic and loathes Europeans. ?

" Not a shade of fanaticism is in me. As a Moslem I naturally set the Moslems above all other peoples, and their religion above all other religions which are utter impostures. Were I an absolute monarch I should obviously deprive myself of the assistance of European gentleman, if not of European ladies, for I know how to make destructions between Europeans well enough. But I am not an absolute monarch.
" Is it a fact, that your Highness is wasting your civil list and personal, fortune in rash extravagance. "

" That is not strictly true. I myself indulge in strict economy, for a Sovereign should set the example of thrift, parsimony and good bargains to his people. Some princes of my family do not seem to look at things in the same light, so I have been obliged to retain in my possession a part of their allowances, of which they made the most deplorable use. Morality ! that is my motto.
(To be Continued. – Sometime).

div.head:
ARMAMENT LIMITATION.
THE TEMPS" ARTICLE.
ATTITUDE OF GERMANY

div.p: According to a competent authority, the interpretation published by the "Temps" of Professor Maartens' declaration is absolutely incorrect If the latter said that the responsibility of a government was grave, which desired to render nugatory the whole Conference by academic discussions on demobilisation, it is impossible to attribute this to Germany, as she is not desirous of making a sine qua-non of the discussion of demobilisation. She will take part at the Conference in spite of sundry reserves and supplementary propositions brought forward by certain states in the Russian programme Consequently if the "Temps" pretends that Germany insists upon the non-discussion of demobilisation as a condition of her participation in the Conference, the "Temps" is wrong. (Reuter) .

In reply to an enquiry Herr Tschirschky stated that the news published by the "Daily Telegraph" and the "Tribune" with reference to the possibility of the retirement of Germany from the Hague Conference was unfounded. He expressed the hope that despite all misrepresentations the closer association of Germany and Great Britain would progress. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE RUMANIAN RIOTS.
RENEWAL OF DISORDERS.

div.p: Despite the optimistic official statements, reports continue to arrive of the most sanguinary encounters between the troops and peasants, the former mercilessly bombarding the villages, the latter showing the fury of des- i peration. Disorders have been renewed in many pacified districts on the withdrawal of the troops for service elsewhere. 120,000 troops are now distributed over the country. (Reuter)

div.head:
MR WHITELEY'S ASSASSIN
HOME SECRETARY ADVISES COMMUTATION.

div.p: Mr. Gladstone has advised the King to commute the sentence passed on Rayner to penal servitude for life.

The "Daily Mail," "Standard," and "Daily Telegraph" denounce the commutation of the sentence as a concession to hysterical emotionalism and a dangerous precedent involving admission of degeneracy as an extenuating circumstance. The "Tribune," "Daily News," and "Morning Leader" approve of the commutation. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE FRENCH IN MOROCCO.
REDUCTION OF FORCES.

div.p: The French force at Ujda is being reduced to small proportions. A buttery of artillery and a squadron of Spahis have returned to Lulla Maghnia. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE KING AND QUEEN IN ITALY
LAUNCHING OF NEW BATTLESHIP.

div.p: It is reported that King Edward and Queen Alexandra will be present at the launch of the battleship "Roma" at Spezzia, King Victor- Emmanuel and Queen Helena will also be present. (Reuter)
Six thousand three hundred tailors have decided to go on strike to-morrow. (Havas)
Sir Henry Elliot is dead. (Reuter)

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN LAND ALLOTMENT CO.
div.p: The following is the report of the directors which was presented to the shareholders at the ordinary general meeting held on Saturday last at the company's offices, Cairo.
(1) The Directors present herewith a statement of the company's audited accounts for the first period of its working, ended 31st December 1906.

(2 Land purchases in Egypt. - The total area of lands, purchased up to the end of 1906 amounted to 2685 fed 16 k, 16 s. These lands represented a capital invested of L.E. 178,091.429 mill, divided as follows :
L.E. mil.
Cost of land 171,495.. 369
New canals, drains, roads,
New buildings and ezbas.................. 1,311 000
Installation of flour mill and
Levelling, destruction of old banks, etc 623 999

(3) Land Sales in Egypt —86 fed. 21 k. 23 s. have been sold for L.E. 10,936 439 mill. L.E. 4,410 573 mill. has been encashed, the remainder being payable in annual instalments stretching over different periods On certain of these lands old canal banks existed, of an especial value for brickmaking. Deducting LE 630 on account of these there remains a sum of L.E. 10,333.439 mill., equivalent in round figures to LE 120 per feddan of agricultural land sold

(4) In accordance with the decision of the extraordinary general meeting held at Cairo on March 12th 1906 the Company has established an Agricultural Bank in Cyprus and has acquired various properties in that island.

(5) The exclusive privilege of establishing an Agricultural Bank in Cyprus has been granted to the company for a period of fifty years to count from January 1st 1907 By the terms of the agreement between the High Commissioner and the company the latter must provide a capital of £100,000 for the Bank; the rate of interest must not exceed nine per cent.; the Government will supply the company with all the information at its disposal as to the registered value and title of the immovable property offered as security ; the Government will assist the company in recovering the annual instalments due through the tax collectors and other Government officials and will receive in consideration of these services one half per cent. of the sums recovered. The Government is also assisting the company in the valuation of the lands offered as security.
By a decree of the High Commissioner the fees due on registration of mortgages has been remitted in cases of loans made by the bank.

The sums advanced by the bank up to December 31st 1906 amount to L.E. 10,141.462 mill. The bank began operations in October during which month two loans were made. The Bank proposes to build stores in which to store agricultural products of the peasants, to advance money on these and to aid the peasants in their sale.

(6, Land purchases in Cyprus—The company has acquired building land inside the town of Famagusta, betwen the quay and the railway station and in the town of Varoshia. Famagusta is the terminus of the railway from Nicosia, the capital of the Island and possesses the only harbour where ships can load and unload alongside in all weathers. The railway and harbour have been recently constructed by the Government. The company is erecting buildings on this property and turning the remainder of the land into fruit and vegetable gardens pending the natural extension of the port The company has acquired in all an area of 163 donums approximately, at an approximate cost of L.E.8,030, equals L.E. 155 per feddan

The company has acquired from the Government and private owners agricultural properties of a total approximate area of 34,000 donums at a total approximate cost of L.E 50,730 : equals L.E.4'2/3 per feddan (Note: a donum is 1600 square yards=/318 feddan.)
The company is reclaiming on a Government concession, an area of 10,000 square yards approximately in extension of the Government quay and adjoining the port railway station.
(7) The profit and loss account shows a profit of LE. 1378 043. It is proposed to place 5% to the. reserve and carry forward the remainder E.E.l 09.141.
(8) The directors beg to propose the re-election of Messrs. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt as auditors for the coming year at a remuneration of L.E.150.
The following is the profit and loss account for the period from 1st November, 1905, to 31st December, 1906.

div.head:
EGYPT AND THE SOUDAN.
FINANCIAL RELATIONS.
div.p: The grant paid by Egypt to the Sudan will be reduced next year by L.E 45,000. Similar reductions will be made annually until the grant is no longer needed The Sudan will then commence to pay an interest of 3 % upon all sums hitherto received. Likewise, commencing with next year, all funds required for public works in the Sudan will be advanced by the Egyptian Government and an interest of 3 % will be charged.
The "Sudan Times" commenting on this news remarks :—

The very important decision which the Egyptian and Sudan Governments have recently arrived at with regard to the financial relations between the two Governments, and which we report to-day will be a turning point in the history of the Sudan. It will effect the whole financial aspect in this country That the Sudan cannot dispense with the financial assistance of Egypt is admitted on all hands, but on the other hand it has been contended that Egyptian funds should not be expended in the Sudan without any return, apart from the many indirect benefits which Egypt derives from a state of peace in this country and the control it now has over the waters of the Nile.

It will be remembered that this arrangement was foreshadowed by Lord Cromer in one of his annual reports on Egypt and the Sudan. None will forget the acrimonious criticism which was directed to the British for their alleged partiality to the Sudan. It was deemed a waste of money to support the Sudan Government until the country was sufficiently developed to defray the expenditure of its government People had objected to the surrender of the Sudan to the Dervishes and they objected to its maintenance when it had been recovered.

The L.E. 45,000 which will be deducted from the next year's grant will be more than compensated for by the Sudan Customs revenues, most of which found its way into the Egyptian Treasury before the opening of Port Sudan. The regular and normal increase in the revenues of the Sudan under an efficient and capable administration is a sufficient guarantee that the country will soon be able to pay its way, and will before long have enough to devote to the important projects which make for the development of its rich rè- 80urces.

A glance at the brief history of the Sudan finance will be sufficient to justify these sanguine hopes The estimated receipts for the first financial year of the government were L.E. 7,000. In seven years' time they reached L.E. 621,943 and the actual receipts will probably exceed this figure by some L.E. 100,000 or more.

div.head:
BILLIARD MATCH AT SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
INTERESTING STRUGGLE.
div.p: There have, in late years, been many interesting and hard fought billiard matches decided on the tables of the magnificent hail of historic Shepheard'8 Hotel, but we question whether any excited so much interest and produced such all round good play as the match between the doyen of markers in Egypt, Percy, and Syers, the well-known and most popular marker of the Grand Continental Hotel.

The circumstances were somewhat out of the ordinary, the supporters of Percy, the winner of the annual tournament this season, putting up a substantial purse for a match between him and Syers, five hundred up on equal terms, Syers previously having always conceded points The Billiard Hall was crowded by half past nine, the time appointed for the opening of the match, and Syer was mainly fancied, although playing on a strange table and with ivory balls, (Syer invariably preferring to play with bonzoline.) Percy immediately settled down to steady work, contributing useful breaks of 15, 21, 18, 19, 18 and 16, whilst Syer after a break of 15 could do nothing, and absolutely stood still at 20, the veteran reaching the first hundred with his opponent 26. Percy continued to forge ahead with comparatively small, but eminently useful, breaks, until at last Syer got into his stride and came away with a pretty break of 30. Percy made a feeble rejoinder, and Syer made a good screw back off the red and got the balls in position, but broke down after compiling 15. He subsequently scored a number of small breaks, and reached his hundred with Percy only 41 ahead. Breaks of 17 and 18 respectively by Percy and Syer followed, and the latter was playing with such confidence that he looked to have the issue in keeping. He passed Percy at 162, putting together an admirable break of 50, and reached 200 with Percy standing at 170. Percy, however, made a series of useful breaks, and at the interval the game stood
Percy 251 Syer 236,
odds being freely laid on the latter player.

On the resumption of the game, after an interval of ten minutes, during which a very handsome collection had been made for the eventual loser, Syer put together 33, and 22 in successive breaks, and claimed 300 with Percy at 271. The latter made a clever break of 42, in which there was some element of luck. Syer again seemed to stand still, and Percy entered the last lap with his opponent having 345 to his credit. Nothing seemed to come amiss to Percy, and Syer experienced on several occasions the worst of luck Percy made breaks of 32, two of 18, and smaller contributions which brought him very near home, when Syer pulled himself together and made a series of beautiful breaks under most difficult conditions. The game closed Percy 500, Syer 433, Percy thus winning a most interesting contest by 67.

div.head: The Egyptian Delta Land & Investment Company, Limited.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the above Company will be held at Winchester House, Old Broad Street in the City of London, on Tuesday, the l6tb day of April, 1907, at 2 o'clock in the afternoon, for the purpose of considering, and if thought fit, passing the following Resolution, or Resolutions to a similar effect. Resolutions, numbered I., II. and III., will, if passed by the requisite majority, be submitted for confirmation to a Second General Meeting to be hereafter convened so as to become Special Resolutions :—
SPECIAL RESOLUTIONS.
I. That the Special Resolution of the Company passed on the 19th day of July 1906, and confirmed on the 16th day of August, 1906, to the effect following:—

"That the Memorandum and Articles of Association be varied as follows:—i. By striking out from Section 3, sub-section (a) of the Memorandum of Association the words 'in any district,' and by substituting for the words 'in which the Railways belonging to, or that may at any time hereafter belong to the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, or any extension or branch thereof existing or hereafter constructed, or proposed to be constructed, may serve or be intended to serve, occurring in the same sub-section the Words 'or the Sudan'
be and is hereby cancelled.
II. That the Articles of Association as altered by Special Resolutions passed and confirmed on the 19th July, 1906, and the 16th August, 1906, respectively, be varied as follows :—

(a) Art. 75.—By adding next after the word "seven" occurring at the end thereof the words "and every exercise of the power to appoint Directors shall be subject to the condition that a majority at least of the Directors shall always be Directors or local Directors of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, while any such person be qualified and willing to act."
(b) Art. 81 — By inserting next after the words " by the Board for election " the words " or a person to be nominated as hereinafter provided by the "Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited. "

(c) Art. 85. — By adding next after the words " he is so interested " appearing in line 5 thereof the words "Provided that this prohibition shall not apply to any contract, dealing or transaction with the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited. "

(d) Art. 86. — By adding next after the word "vacant" occurring in such Article the words " If any Director appointed by the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, as a first Director, or subsequently under this Article shall cease to be a Director, otherwise than by retirement by rotation, and on retiring by rotation shall not thereupon be re-elected, the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, may by writing delivered within one month of his ceasing to be a Director, at a place in Egypt to be appointed by the Board, or at the registered office of this Company nominate a successor, and on such nomination with a consent in writing by the person nominated to act being so delivered, the person nominated, if qualified, shall become a Director, and take the place of the Director to whom he succeeds. "
(e) Art. 87.—By inserting at the commencement thereof before the word "Any" the words "Save as aforesaid."
(f) Art. 90.— By inserting next after the words "in Egypt" the words "provided he be approved by the Board of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited."

III. That it is desirable that the business and affairs of the Company should henceforth be managed and directed entirely from Egypt, and that accordingly the Articles of Association as altered by Special Resolutions passed and confirmed on the 19th July, 1906, and the 16th August, 1906, respectively, be further varied as follows:—
(a) Art. 4-—By inserting next after the word "Board" first occurring therein, the words "in Cairo."
(b) Art. 27.—By striking out the words "A Local Board or Agent abroad" and all subsequent words.
(c) Art. 28.—By inserting next after the word "kept" the words "in Cairo."
(d) Art. 43.—By inserting next before the word "London" the word "Cairo."
(e) Art. 46.—By inserting next before the words "as the office," the words "at a place in Egypt to be appointed by the Board or."
(f) Art 49.—By inserting next after the word "lodge" occurring in line 2 thereof, the words "at a place in Egypt to be appointed by the Board or."
(g) Art. 50.—By inserting next after the words "such other place" the words "in Egypt and elsewhere "

(h) Art. 72.—By inserting next after the words "place of address" where they occur in such Article the words "in Egypt or"; by inserting next before the words "the registered office of the Company" occurring in such Article, the words "a place in Egypt to be appointed by the Board or," and before the word "Office" lastly occurring the words "place or."
(i) Art. 81.—By inserting next after the word 'leave" the words "at a place in Egypt to be appointed by the Board or."
(j) Art. 90.—By striking out the words "in England, they may also appoint any Managing Director or Manager."
(k) Art. 93.—By substituting for the words "go abroad" the words 'leave Egypt"
(l) Art. 94.—By striking out such Article and substituting therefor the following Article :—

" Boards shall be held when and where the Directors shall think fit provided they be held in Egypt, and all Boards shall be held in Cairo until otherwise determined. Notice of Board Meetings need not be given to Directors not in Egypt at the date of the issue of such notice. "
(m) Art. 111. By inserting at the beginning of such Article the words " The Seal shall be kept in Egypt and '' and by striking out the word "abroad. "

(n) Art. 116. — By substituting for the word "abroad" first occurring the words " out of Egypt, " and for the word "four" the word "two." By striking out sub­clauses 1 and 2 of such Article, and by striking out from sub-clause 3 the words " the members of or any of the members of any local board established as aforesaid or in favour of. "
(o) Art. 123. — By inserting next after the words "at such place" appearing in line 7 thereof the words "in Egypt."

(p) Art. 124. — By inserting next after the word "Company" secondly occurring the words to be held in Egypt;" and by inserting next before the words "at the office of the Company" occurring in such Article the words "at such place in Egypt as the Board shall appoint or. "
(q) Art 125. —By inserting at the end the words "Every meeting convened under this Article shall as in the case of General meetings be held in Egypt."
(r) Art. 126.—By substituting for the words "in the United Kingdom" the words "in Egypt."
(s) Art. 131.—By inserting next before the words "at the office" occurring in line 7 thereof the words "at the place in Egypt appointed by the Board or."
(t) Art. 136 —By substituting for the word "London" the word "Egyptian."
(u) Art. 138.—By inserting next after the words "the Board" the words ' to be held in Egypt."
(v) Art. 139.—By inserting next after the word "members" the words "to be held in Egypt."
(w) Art. 154.—By inserting next before the words "at the office" the words "at such place in Egypt as the Board shall appoint or."
(x) Art. 157.—By inserting next after the words "to be kept" the words "in Egypt."

(y) Art 176 —By inserting next after the words "addresses registered" the words "in Egypt or" ; by substituting for the word "London" the word "Egyptian" ; by inserting next after the words "place of address" the words "in Egypt or" and by inserting next after the word "lying" occurring in line 11 thereof, the words "at a place in Egypt to be appointed by the Board or."
ORDINARY RESOLUTIONS.
IV. That the Capital of the Company be and is hereby increased from £250,000 to £500,000.

V. That the Directors be and are hereby authorised to enter into an Agreement with the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, whereby it shall be agreed that Clauses 3 and 4 of an Agreement dated the 21st day of April, 1904, and made between the Company of the one part, and the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, of the other part, which said Clauses were cancelled by a letter dated the 27th July, 1906, shall be restored so as again to be of full force and effect.
By order of the Board,
F. J. Horne,
Secretary.
211, Gresham House,
Old Broad Street, E C.,
Dated 27th March, 1907.

Shareholders who hold Warrants to Bearer are reminded that if they wish to attend the Extraordinary General Meeting of the Company they must first deposit their Bearer Warrants, together with a statement in writing of their names and addresses, either at the Registered Office of the Company in London, two clear days before the Meeting, i.e., not later than the 13th April, or in Egypt with the National Bank of Egypt, the Bank of Egypt, the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Limited, Credit Lyonnais, or the Imperial Ottoman Bank, ten clear days before the date of the meeting, i e, not later than 5th April, the Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held.
Each Depositor will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange for the Share Warrants deposited, which must be produced by the holders attending the Meeting. 29904-6-2.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de fer et des Télégraphes dé l'Etat a l'honneur d'infonner le Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au 20 Avril prochain a midi des offres pour l'extraction et 1er fournitnre de 50,000 mètres cubes de ballast provenant de la carrière de Khatatbeh; et ce conformement aux clauses et conditions du Cahier des Charges dont on peut prendre connaissance au Service Central de la Voie et des Travaux au Caire.
Pour être admis a concourir, le soumissionnaire devra verser au préalable à titre de dépôt provisoire LE 60 et joindre le reçu a son offre.

Dans le cas où il serait déclaré adjudicataire, il devra dans un délai de 24 heures à'partir de la réception de l'avis qui lui sera donné, completer ce cautionnement provisoire et le porter à LE. 250.

Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de 80 millièmes et rédigées conformément au modèle de soumission annexé au cahier des charges dont on peut obtenir copie au Bureau Central du Service de la Voie contre paiement de P.T. 5.
Elles seront adressées par la Poste sous pli recommandé à :—
Monsieur le Directeur Général, des Chemins de fer de l'Etat et des Télégraphes
Le Caire
et sous double envelope. l'intérieur portant l'inscription suivante :—
Offre pur l'extraction et la fourniture de ballast de Khattatbah."
L'Administration n'est pas tenue d'accepter l'offre la plus basse ni de donner suite aux soumissions présentées,
Le Caire, le 27 Mars, 1907. 29900-2 2

Le Caire, le 27 Mars 1907. 29898-2-2-

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication le transport de la caillasse pendant une année.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 20 (vingt).
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Technique où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours dé 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous cacheté à Monsieur l'Adminstrateur de le Municipalité avant le 9 Avril 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées én séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : "Soumission pour Transport de la Caillasse. "

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des chargés, devra être remis séparément an Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 9 Avril 1907 à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur
(Signé) W. P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 27 Mars 1907. 29902-3-2

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Le lundi 15 Avril 1907 de 10 heures du matin à midi, la Municipalité procédera à la vente aux enchères publiques à la Rue Chounet el Taïnat à Minet el Charagoua N° 18, d'une quantité d'environ 130 poutrelles en fer de 12 mètres de longueur occupant la voie publique.

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'enchère de 1 % et déposer le 25 % de la valeur de la marchandise achetée au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral à la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de l'adjucation.
Ils devront enlever les poutrelles achetées dans un délai de dix jours sous peine de folle enchère pour compte de l'adjudicataire et de perte du dépôt de 25 %.
L'Administrateur
(signé) W. P. Chataway
Alexandrie, le 27 Mars 1907. 29903 3-2

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
